149095597.review:
So, that's what a pastry chef does... spread his "cream" everywhere.

[h1] Introduction [/h1]

Nekopara Vol. 4 is the latest (and probably last) part of the series. Not gonna lie, they took a bit more risks with this one from a writing standpoint. Let's see if those risks paid off or not.

[h1] Worldbuilding [/h1]

The worldbuilding elements in this game remained the same as the previous games, but with an important addition: catgirls don't exist only on Japan. There are catgirls in other countries, and the story does a brief explanation on them, specifically, the bell test and of how they differ depending on the country, pretty much like driving licenses work in different countries. Like what happened with Vol. 3, I appreciate that these new elements were introduced through dialogue instead of exposition dumps. They were also introduced within context, which is good. The only problem I see with this is that some worldbuilding elements, like the existence of the bell test in other countries, don't have any bearing on the story, because it's information the reader don't need in order to understand character payoffs or plot points. One rule of thumb when describing worldbuilding elements, is that they need to have some relevance to the plot or to the characters. Otherwise, it's just unnecessary bloat.

[h1] The plot [/h1]

Unlike the earlier installments, this game's narrative focus is on the main character, which embarks on a journey to discover the real motivation behing his cake-making. I spotted a couple of contrivances, especially mid-game, when Kashou travels to other country, and he encounters Shigure there. It was established that Shigure attended to school, so it's reasonable to assume that she is underage, so, how did she board a plane, when it was never established that minors could travel to other countries without an adult? I stress this because the presence of Shigure in that country is important for one of the big payoffs of the story, which is a plot twist I saw coming a mile away. And the funny thing was if Shigure wasn't present abroad, it wouldn't change anything, because Kashou would have been told the secret anyway by his mother, who was privy to said secret. So, the presence of Shigure was a totally avoidable contrivance. The pacing was off in some instances, because there were scenes that went for longer than needed, and there were some tonal clashes here and there, but nothing too damaging.

[h1] The characters [/h1]

In my review of Vol. 3 I said that that game was setting up a character arc for Kashou. Well, here it is. It's mostly well done, because there are issues. Earlier in the game, something happens that made Kashou stray from his path, and it establishes a flaw for him, which is his pride. The problem I see with this, is that that flaw was established in a circunstance that's convenient to the plot. In character writing, flaws are introduced early on in the story, and only become relevant when they turn into obstacles that get in the way of a character's development. In this case, Kashou being prideful was never established in the previous game, so it strikes me as just a way to create conflict when there should be none. I'd have written a scene when he is shown as prideful during the first game which doesn't create any meaningful conflict. There are new characters also. There are Kashou's parents, Minaduki Awayuki, who is a plot device, and Minaduki Suhama, who acts as an obstacle Kashou needs to overcome. He actually grows a little as a character. There is also Beignet, which is Kashou's mentor, and it's relevant to the payoff at the end, and Fraise, a new catgirl which formed part of Kashou's past. Shigure's brother complex reached new heights of insanity, by the way, and the catgirls acted as support for Kashou, and they remained as likable and endearing as ever.

[h1] Presentation [/h1]

Not much to say about sound design, soundtrack, voice acting and performance. But the art direction suffered a massive improvement over the previous games. The backgrounds are gorgeous, detailed, sharp and rich in color. Character artstyle saw some minor changes, but the color grading on the sprites is a bit different, more muted than in the previous games. H-scenes went back to run at 30 fps, but the animations are more detailed and there are other animations not present in previous games, like body fluids. By the way, if you want the 18+ patch for this game, you need to go to an external site to get it. Refer to guides on how to do it.

In conclusion:

[b] Pros: [/b]

-Much needed development for Kashou.
-Vastly Improved art direction.
-Improved writing, with some notable exceptions.
-Improved animations in H-scenes.

[b] Cons: [/b]

-There are notable writing issues present in the story.
-It's harder to get the 18+ patch now.

At the end, taking more risks paid off, to a reasonable extent, because there are still issues. But the slice-of-life elements are as good as in the previous games, and the characters are still likable and endearing. Granted, Kashou's mother is, like I said, a plot device, but she still has a personality at least. And there is the improvements in the artistic front, which are massive. With all that said, despite the issues I mentioned, the core essence of the game remained untouched, so it's still a solid recommendation for readers. And, at 18 hours, you get plenty of reading time for the price.

137152217.review:
[h1]Christmas catpanions, fully grown edition.[/h1]

[b][u]PROS[/u]:[/b] Nekopara Vol.4 is the 4th in line, but 6th released game in the series.  It continues the lighthearted fluff the series is known for, keeping to their roots of simple kinetic visual novel story, with charming art & pleasant music alongside it (though many of the tracks are the same as all previous titles).  This one has a stronger focus on Kashou, the title character, rather than any of the girls.  This is actually a welcome change of pace, showcasing aspects of the character's insecurities & desire to improve his craft.  It also gives a bit of the focus onto Shigure, Kashou's little sister, & thankfully Kashou's continual pushback on her romantic relations of her.  Besides that, the VN is what one would expect from the series by this point.

[b][u]CONS[/u]:[/b] At this point, the cons are consistent, & it has become clear that they're built into the framework of the series.  As stated in previous reviews, the slightly uncanny valley effect the moving characters have can be a little unnerving, but the series is known for it at this point.  With this, it becomes more difficult to not just copy this section out from previous reviews.

[b][u]ACHIEVEMENTS[/u]:[/b] Nothing changes with these titles, just another simple list the requires only the effort of making one's way through the story.

[b][u]FINAL[/u]:[/b] Nekopara Vol.4 is just another entry in the Nekopara series.  The story beats are a little different each time, but it really does nothing to attempt to grab readers & make each title stand out as something different from every other title.  It still is competent, but it's done nothing besides just being more of the same.  For fans of the series, this makes it as easy recommendation, but for anyone else, it's more difficult.  As it's harmless, I can't give it a negative recommendation, though starting at part 4 of a story that doesn't care about catching new readers up or crafting a story that can be told by itself should let one know they should start at Vol.1 for a proper try.

136996880.review:
I played the entire game on my docked steam deck on the living room TV in front of my parents. 
Nekopara Volume 4 Neko to Patissier no Noel is surely a masterpiece that can be enjoyed with the whole family. [strike] if they want it or not [/strike]
My parents are proud of me and never once have they questioned my sanity or thought about what could've possibly gone wrong with their parenting for me to have ended up like this. 
Vol. 4 is by far the most polished, but also the most censored one. compared to the previous volumes this one follows more of a story, building more family lore, introducing new characters, and giving Kashou, but also Shigure more character development. It doesn't have cutesy elements in between the storyline of the volume, and is, therefore, more linear, with chapters being an hour long instead of 20-30 minutes. That doesn't make Volume in any way inferior to the previous ones though, like I said it feels way more polished. For people who came for the story just like me, this is the most enjoyable volume because you can barely even tell where the lewd scenes might be. There's just one "suggestive" scene towards the end, which only takes like a minute or something. For people that came for that aspect, however... You should get the patch. (Denpasoft or dlsite, you're welcome) 

Lastly, I liked Shigure already before, but after reading chapter 4 she proves that even in a world full of catgirls, you don't have to be a catgirl to be best girl. Shigure was so cute and beautiful, same with Fraise. I'm excited to see them together in Nekopara After, I don't doubt that it can be just as good if not better.

130041016.review:
The last [spoiler]last?[/spoiler] game of the Nekopara Series continues the story of the prodigal son who left his rich family's household to [strike]form a catgirl harem, who wouldn't?[/strike] start a western bakery in Japan. In this volume you will learn more about the Minaduki family itself, instead of focusing on the catgirls. Which you should know well enough already [strike]some of you, [b]TOO WELL[/b][/strike].

The story continues more or less serious with the wholesomeness/humour being brought up every now and always by the six catgirls and Shigure. I won't talk anything further to avoid giving spoilers, but it has some revelations and a nice development. On the downside, there is no character development left here, since you should already know all the significant heroines. Their screentime is well balanced, with maybe Chocola and Vanilla being a tiny little bit more on the spotlight when compared to the other catgirls, but that was fine.

The engine was improved, the animations are way richer now, btw. They have more expressions, poses and the talking animations match super well the voice acting. There are some cutscenes which might require some Windows codecs now too. You can still pet catgirls [spoiler]drooling...[/spoiler] and you can still read subtitles in Japanese AND English, if you're practicing/learning Kanji.

Achievements worked fine, nothing to complain there. No Linux port and Steam Protons started acting up because of the cutscene codecs. I managed to play with Proton 5.13 with
[code]PROTON_USE_WINED3D=1 %command%[/code]
Cutscenes will show as a blackscreen but at least it won't crash.

I did enjoy the direction the franchise was going, but apparently the developers decided to capitalize on the nekophiles [spoiler]person who loves catgirls[/spoiler] in the market and make the next one a Gacha game. Nope. Definitely no. Nope, nope, nope. So this is probably the last one we will be seeing in a long while. Enjoy!

120734756.review:
As usual the story is very nicely detailed with the usual mix of comedy and pathos.  The only slight downside was the French section - the story did seem to drag along there (mainly due to the amount of fawning Shigure does over Fraise).  It was nice to see why the protagonist and his father's relationship was a bit testy.

There are few mention of societal problems this time around (beyond the fact that the French Bell Exam is harder than the Japanese one), so the story just revolves around the protagonist and the girls ([spoiler]ending with group sex at the end[/spoiler])

It was certainly nice to see Milk again too.  Shigure's love for her brother takes a creepy turn in this episode, as when they're in France, she more or less openly states she wants sex.

I had originally thought this would be the last episode, but with Nekopara After: La Vraie Famille being released (probably next year), I may get that as well to round off the series.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Nekopara Vol. 4

It's a great storytelling visual novel but with new characters introduction.

Unlike all nekopara, this one takes place in whole new different scenarios as the main character struggles to find motivation of his work. His father disapproves his baking leads him to go back to his mentor who taught him baking when he was young. 

As for now, I give a small spoiler as there are new catgirl called Fraise will be introduce soon. 

Now for the game main purpose, the eroge scenes got a major improvement from all nekopara. I'm surprised as it also using fluid animation movement during these eroge scenes. Yes we got all the six catgirls from previous Nekopara have their own *seperate* scenes. Good thing about this game NSFW and SFW options before entering the eroge scenes. 

Sad to say the DLC uncensored patch of the game needed to buy separately from other online VN store because steam somehow don't sale these anymore like previous nekopara would do.

For my own review, the game is great and I'm enjoying both story and eroge scenes of the game. I probably think there will be a new nekopara after this since there is some new characters and developments. 9/10 I love Fraise so much :3.

109468021.review:
[b]November 21st, 2021[/b]

"Hey, if you fall down the mountain, I'll buy you Volume 4."

I was streaming Getting Over It for my friends on this fateful day, the pains of Volumes 2 & 3 now behind me, my next goal was to get over the mountain for the second time, or third, or fourth; I can't remember which. As luck would have it, my friend had made this deal with me, that he would buy me Nekopara: Volume 4 if I were to ride the infamous, dastardly snake all the way back to the beginning of the game.

Needless to say, I played this game. Whether my trip down the mountain was on purpose or accidental, I'll leave that for the reader to decide. That part is not important. The soul-draining-yet-entertaining Nekopara franchise had plenty left in store for me, and Volume 4 was the next natural step in this journey. I didn't even have to pay for it this time, what a treat!

My journey picked up from the end of Volume 3. My lingering and burning questions about the catgirl slave society had since been accompanied by questions regarding the origins of catgirls as a whole. What were they designed for? Can they breed, or are they manufactured in a lab somewhere? Who would devote research to such a task and why? These are questions I had neglected to address in my Volume 3 review, and for that I apologize (lmao who the fuck reads these things anyway).

There was an additional question that I had which, unlike my other questions, would actually be answered by Volume 4. "Where is there to go after all of the main catgirls are in my harem?" I had suspicions that we would be going somewhere into Kashou's past someway or another, as he alludes to his time studying abroad in Fr*nce several times throughout Volumes 2 & 3. The part I was unsure of was how exactly the plot would get Kashou to face a trial like this, so I was going into this with the slightest hint of curiosity, even if I knew the game wasn't going to be any piece of literature genius.

But before I get into the story of Volume 4, it's time for a detour into some things I have yet to discuss in detail throughout these reviews: the main character Kashou Minaduki, and, without a doubt, the absolute worst, and most infuriating aspect of this entire series; Shigure Minaduki, Kashou's younger sister.

Kashou Minaduki is the mostly invisible main character of the Nekopara series. He was born into a family who has owned a traditional Japanese sweet shop for generations, but discovers during his years in culinary school that he has an affinity for "Western-style" sweets, studying under the wing of a Fr*nch patissiere. Some time passes between him returning home (during which the events of Extra and Vol. 0 occur) and leaving to open his own shop that specializes in the pastries and cakes he made during his tenure in Fr*nce. He is also a massive fucking idiot, a fact that fucking CINNAMON, of all people, brings up. Keep this in mind as it will be important soon.

Shigure Minaduki is a perverted cat-lady (not a catgirl, thought i'd make that clear) who has an unhealthy (and sexual) obsession for her older brother. I hope you can already see why this is bad, since I pretty much summed up her entire raison d'etre for the entire series; being the catgirls's owner and mentor is a thinly veiled excuse to state otherwise. She has an ENTIRE PLAN surrounding getting her catgirls to "get close" to Kashou so that she herself can "get close" when they have done their jobs. Kashou knows about this, but being the idiot he is, does jack-all in trying to stop her and her shenanigans, and that's when he even notices at all, because 90% of the time he's too oblivious to get a clue. This further encourages Shigure to simp (what would simping be for girls? she-simping? shimping?) for her brother since he's too stupid to stop her and she's too crazed to stop. Also, did I mention that she's still in high school, about 16 I'd estimate, while Kashou is around 25-26. What the actual fuck? She doesn't have the excuse of "catgirl maturity" as a crutch this time.

I felt it important to bring up Kashou and (especially) Shigure here because the game has Shigure in it too often, and the scenes with her are particularly unsettling, in a bad way. Shigure follows Kashou halfway across the world on a whim, and if that wasn't enough, she lets herself get fingered by Kashou while he's sleeping, (a section which ranks up there with Yanderedev's Persona 3 fanfic and that one Vaporeon copypasta as one of the most painful things I've ever read, thank fuck it wasn't graphic). This stuff made parts of this game EXTREMELY uncomfortable, actively making it worse in the process. Not saying there weren't similar scenes in other games either, they're just particularly bad here.

It's a shame too, because other than that, the story isn't bad. Kashou's arc about him looking to improve his baking wasn't bad. Kashou's dad, Fraise, and Beignet were, while generic (as usual), still pretty enjoyable presences that were relevant to the plot. The culmination at the end was surprisingly well executed, considering this is Nekopara we're talking about. There were some callbacks that made this Volume the most fun one to stream via Discord. The later Nekopara Volumes were noticeable improvements in the storytelling of these games from the early ones, to the point which I'd actually call them competent. Not anything super [i]good[/i], just competent. It's kind of a shame, to be honest, that what could've potentially been an un-ironic 6/10 game got so muddled by it's worst aspect that it dragged itself down. Don't get me wrong, this game is pure gold in an ironic sense, like most of the games in this series, which is why I've rated them all thumbs up so far. However, when I have to go into more detail about this game's worst aspect more than all of it's best ones combined, then that speaks quite a bit on what's holding this game back from actual goodness.

So what have I learned from seeing this series through to it's conclusion? Not what I was hoping for, believe it or not. So what comes next? Is it the end for me? No Volume 0, 1, Extra, or Catboy's Paradise? Well, take one look at my profile and you will know that's not the case. I'm still only halfway done with this series, and there's still so many questions on the table to remain unanswered. Volume 4 is not the end for me; not by a long shot.

tl;dr: nya nya catgirl game 4 has good aspects held back by (REDACTED), questions still unanswered. 5/10.

106721236.review:
I have never in my life been so thoroughly bored playing a game. Even titles like Crackhead, which I consider a complete waste of time and money, provided more entertainment than this. Visual novel games, such as the one in question, often run the risk of being inherently dull due to their heavy reliance on reading comics. However, many manage to inject excitement through mini-games or meaningful choices, which is sorely lacking here.

Beyond its monotonous gameplay, this game manages to make me uncomfortably ill at ease. It's difficult to recommend it, as it appears to cater exclusively to those with a particular penchant. While I may jokingly refer to myself as one for indulging in adult-oriented games, I cannot fathom aligning myself with individuals who genuinely derive pleasure from this specific title.

Progressing through this game feels like an arduous task, a genuine chore. I only persevere due to the desire to unlock achievements and, admittedly, the small pleasure of being able to interact with the characters through petting, a modest yet appreciated addition. Unfortunately, the game's increasing length serves only to exacerbate the frustration, as it entails enduring more of its hollow content.

It's as if this game has plunged me into previously uncharted depths of despair. While I thought I had reached rock bottom before, leading an existence devoid of social connections, this game series has managed to drag me even further into negative territory. While others may speak of New Life+ experiences, I find myself dwelling in an Anti-Life realm, a desolation that I wouldn't wish upon anyone.

For those seeking entertainment, I would suggest turning to the anime adaptation instead. It offers a relatively enjoyable experience, free from the drawbacks and discomfort found within the game. However, I strongly caution against subjecting oneself to the tediousness and unease that accompany playing this title.

105685518.review:
Nekopara Volume 4 is quite excellent, for those who enjoy visual novels or reading enjoyable stories, give this game a shot. The whole game series are some of the most cute and wholesome games out there, ready to make anyone feel happy. Usually when I'm angry because of something that happened in my life, I tend to stay mad for a while. That is, until I started playing the Nekopara games, as they never failed to soothe and calm me down, they always made me smile.

Nekopara Volume 4 differs quite drastically from the previous installments of the franchise, because of the change in looks. The Nekopara series always looked nice, but for this game, they polished the UI quite a bit, made the graphics stunningly fantastic, and the game is in 1080p. Unlike all 5 other Nekopara games preceding this one, Volume 4 chooses to focus on our main character, Kashou, and his personal life. This is a quite welcome change of pace because the games were mostly focused on the catgirls previously. But don't worry, the catgirls still get a healthy amount of attention here too. Volume 4 often feels like a movie, seeing new and old characters be introduced, watching the character development, and looking at a bunch of cute catgirls. Volume 4 also boasts quite a decent soundtrack. Most of the tracks are instrumentals, but that's perfectly fine, as they're still quite excellent. The music can range from upbeat and calming to emotional and sorrowful.

All this praise does not come with no drawbacks, as there are a few things that may dissuade someone from trying the game out due to preferences. For one, there aren't any branching paths to deal with, no dialogue trees, and no minigames or other such distractions. It's a purely linear narrative. However, the game makes up for this, as it's so easy to sit back and relax while watching this cute and sweet story unfold that the game doesn't really need any alternative features to actually entice you. Due to the meandering nature of the game, there are points in the game where you feel like nothing is being accomplished narratively, and that you're just staring blankly for no reason. However, these moments don't last long at all, and the game is always able to entertain me long enough to the point where these dry points in the game can be neglected.

Now onto the hentai, because the Nekopara games are quite infamous for it. In short, the hentai is quite good. The scenes are extensive and very detailed, with about five total scenes in the game. To me, only coming to the Nekopara games just to jerk off is quite wasteful, as the games have much more to offer than just that. But, if you really only came to jerk off to the hentai scenes, then you won't be disappointed, because they're of high quality.

Overall, if you're a fan of visual novels and want a cute and relaxing story to calm you down, I highly suggest Nekopara Volume 4, and the rest of the games as well. After all, who doesn't enjoy adorable catgirls?

As someone who has played all the previous Nekopara titles, including the free VR title, I feel like a serious review of the latest game is in order.

Nekopara Vol. 4 is the latest installment of the Nekopara series, spearheaded by Sayori-san. The game itself is a visual novel with the optional R-18 patch to install. The game itself is not that long, totaling around 5-6 hours depending on your reading speed. 

In Vol. 4, the story is Kashou-centric with his catpanions offering him support. We finally learn a little more about his family and past. He no longer is that MC with no face, he is Kashou Minaduki owner of the patisserie "La Soleil". If you got the R-18 patch, yes, there will a lot of scenes with all this catpanions. They truly outdid themselves this time around. 

While the narrative itself is no more than your normal drama show, it certainly is enough to keep your reading. I like how linear the story is and doesn't waste time getting to the heart of the matter. While Nekopara doesn't take any strong risks in writing, it does add in a nice twist in this volume. As always, all the cat girls are always fun and sweet to see, never a dull moment. 

Some may ask, do I have to play the previous Volumes in order to play this one? I mean, it's an eroge VN at the end of the day and if that's what you're looking for, don't worry about it. But to those that care, yes, the Volumes should be played in order because it is a continuous story. 

Honestly, the Nekopara series is one of the best Visual Novels on the market, you can't deny it. Not for its great story, but for the absolutely stellar artwork, Live 2D work and voice acting. And of course, for us degenerates, the H-Scenes. 

When Sayori-san set out to make Nekopara Vol. 1 I'm sure they didn't expect all this attention. But you can tell they love what they do and we do too. Hell, they even made a Cat Boys Paradise game and everyone thought it was an April Fools. Sike, get pranked, Sayori knows what people like and they will keep doing it. 

Will there be a Vol. 5? Hard to tell really. Maybe. They did introduce the new cat girl, implied she should come work at La Soleil and left it at that. I'm honestly quite satisfied the game even reached Vol. 4, I never expected it and if Sayori-san decides to make a Vol. 5 I will be more than grateful. Though it might be awhile because they recently welcomed a newborn to their family. To them, I wish them all the best.

NEKOPARA Vol. 1 changed the world and us. It awakened and outted the degenerates. It brought us a good time during the the bad times. And now here we stand on NEKOPARA Vol. 4. Whether you're just now joining the party or a veteran, I applaud you for following your desires. Cheers.

Review:

Compared to the original series, it's had such a major overhaul that you could call it a remaster. To name a couple of things I wanna point out, firstly, the (main) characters' details are astounding, simulating lighting and raytracing in real time while keeping the character models not too oversaturated and shiny. Furthermore, the story as a visual novel has had many elements to give the dialogues more natural feelings (such as character reactions to each other's conversations in real time).
Lastly, despite being a slice of life series, a genre that's usually underappreciated and maybe shunned by cultured intellectual weebs and chads alike, the level of details combined with the Nekopara series' unique mix of comedy and drama throughout really makes the experience enjoyable and relaxing.
One more thing that I forgot to mention: the soundtrack. As 7-8/10 as the ol' classics are, not much has changed. And honestly, I can't tell if the same songs being used again scene after scene is a blessing or a curse. Nevertheless, the new ones ain't so bad, 7-7.5/10. Personal fav? Nyanko to Bansan.
That being said, *because* it's a slice of life, you can indulge in the mishaps and goofiness of it completely braindead and pay no heeds to deep stuff (no pun intended), and that's fine. However, if you're someone who can only appreciate better quality-of-life types of visual novels, this 4th installment of the Nekopara series is highly recommended.




Heads up to anyone getting their hands on the 18+ patch for the 1st time (which I totally didn't pirate), there's a threesome right at the beginning. And a lil' something at the end, whose image will burn into your eyes, soul and 20 other body parts that you might not recognize. Just lettin' ya know.
Have a good one.

99973749.review:
Nekopara Vol. 4.... finally focuses on Kashou's development as a character and introduces his (and Shigure's) father and mother.


The story:
Nekopara Vol. 4 starts with Kashou's mothers birthday, but Kashou's father is not happy with his sons cooking and says that "something is missing". Desperate to appeal to his fathers taste and be worthy in his families eyes Kashou flies back to France in order to re-learn from his old mentor. Shigure joins Kashou and they both arrive at his mentors house and meet another cat-girl, Fraise. Kashou asks his mentor if she could teach him and he explains his situation to no avail, she says he must find this "ingredient" on his own. After checking out the cakes him and Shigure go back to Japan. The next day is the big day, it's Christmas Eve and it's the day Kashou has to prove himself worthy to his father, and in order to prove himself worthy to his father he makes a small cake based on his mentors with a little bit of a Japanese tint. His father enjoys the cake and all is good, but Kashou also finds out why his father had a problem... his mentor is actually his grandma who abandoned her son at a young age to keep the shop from going under. 


The characters:
This entry mainly focuses on our MC, Kashou, but has a little bit of focus on Shigure and slightly develops the rest of the cat-girls. It allows for Kashou to grow out of being a 1 dimensional typical harem protagonist who gives advice to the girls and bakes cakes by giving him his own character arc, which while not perfect is still pretty good.


H-scenes:
Here's a massive gripe I have with this entry. All of the sex scenes have this really rigid, and stiff feel to them and you can really like feel that it's a GIF. The previous games had very smooth H-scenes and they (at least to me) looked much hotter and much better. The voices during the scenes were still good as always and it's nice that they included Christmas outfits for a few of the scenes.


Music:
A few new tracks were added for the French sections of the game and one extra track in the Japanese part. All of it sounds good and I don't really have a gripe with it.


Conclusion:
I enjoy this entry about as much as Vol. 3 and I like that they at least attempted to make Kashou an interesting character. There's some genuinely hard-hitting scenes in this entry and it was overall really fun. I'll give it an 8/10!

Well, Volume 4.

Gotta say, I really enjoyed this one. It follows through Kashou's growth as a person, and we see him transform into a much more mature and I guess responsible character, and MC growth is something we don't always see in this genre of games so it's great to see an entire damn game focused on it. The first three volumes focus on the interpersonal relationships between the catgirls and Kashou, whilst this one focuses on the character of Kashou itself.
The catgirls are, of course, cute as all heck and it's always heat-warming to see them go about their day. Though I feel like the amount Chocola and Coconut were bouncing around was a tad excessive.  Furthermore, chad Kashou having a seven-some.
We also saw 4 new characters introduced, as well as a character from an earlier game re-introduced.
Fraise is a really cute character, in both physical and behavioural aspects. Her character design is cute as heck, and her personality is adorable.
Mentor, or Beignet-san, is also a pretty cool character, and boy, that was a twist at the end there. Though, to be honest, I could see something like that happening from when we first met Beignet.
We also meet Kashou's parents and we explore the "feud" but not really a feud between Kashou and his dad, and also experience his mom's big-tiddy ara ara energy.

Overall, a good game, and I can't wait until Volume 5.

Side note: what the f is the age difference between Kashou's parents.

94428689.review: Nekopara Volume 4 changed the world. The highly anticipated fourth installment in the Nekopara franchise, Nekopara Volume 4, exceeded all the high expectations bestowed upon it and single-handedly managed to illustrate to all of humanity, what in life, is truly important. I understand fully that my opening statement will leave some under the impression that this review is satire, however, I shall dispel these doubts to the greatest of my abilities for what I have said is not an "unfounded" nor "egregious" claim, but one that I will defend till the day that I die. To begin with contextualization; in the midst of the Covid-19 pandemic that decimated economies, led to the untimely deaths of many unfortunate victims, and polarized entire nations on what actions and protocols were necessary to mitigate the pernicious effects of this pandemic, a singular game arose to, just for a moment in time, provide an experience that could take away all of the worrying, stress, and anxiety of the world and replace it with joy, love, and confirmation that everything would be alright. This game was of course, Nekopara Volume 4. A life changing experience for all those who've played it. With it's complex, but not confusing plot, lovable, but not generic characters, and breathtaking, but not overwhelming art, it is no suprise why so many around the world, including myself, call this game life changing. This game, through its myriad of subtle nuances and morally upstanding themes, humanity was reminded of the fact that relationships with others close to you were what was important. This common theme in the game was just one of many praiseworthy aspects of the game, so as to say that this theme, albeit common throughout the game, did not send a powerful message felt all throughout the world, because it evidently did. To preface, I played this game before playing any of the other Nekopara games. But I don't think it really matters, I could follow the story perfectly. Plus I already know the basic stuff from the first Nekopara game.

Anyway, if you like very well designed and cute catgrils with distinctive personalities, then this is the game for you. Ditto for great art and good music.

If you actually want like, a good story, this game isn't it. The story is just kind of boring. I'm genuinely shocked I ended up clocking less than 10 hours on this game, it feels like it ran for a lot more. Its hard to describe why the story is bad other than it just feels shallow and uninteresting. There's just no real hook to it and the climax points of the story don't really hit that well. None of the catgirls actually go through any kind of character arc in this game, The main plot twist was also dumb and should be obvious to anyone above 10 years old long before Awayuki finally reveals it. Finally, the core message at the end is a fucking reach. The main character overcomes a personal flaw that never fucking existed to begin with. Don't fucking tell me that Kashou didn't consider other people's feelings, that's just objectively wrong. Apparently the other nekopara games had better story and writing. Might play them one day; 

I would normally still give a game like this a positive recommendation simply because its technically and aesthetically a sound game and I can obviously see its appeal. But for someone who plays games for the story, I just can't make myself say this is a good game because I really didn't enjoy most of it.

91473261.review:
This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

91257358.review:
I've been following Nekopara for a bit now. It's over the top overly cutsie overly lovey dovey stuff. I can't get enough of it, it's cute and playful. 
Nekopara 4 is a pretty big move for nekopara. While it has roughly the same length of story as the rest of the games, it has a much higher amount of CG's and plot points to go along with them. The game is pretty impressive over all, a stand out technically among visual novels. They've even added something I wish the other games had, alternititves to the 18+ scenes that you usually have to buy DLC to get. I've never been fond of those scenes in the game, they just make me feel gross. In past games, if you didn't have the DLC you would simply be skipped past them. In this game, there's an alternative more wholesome option, meaning there aren't simply random gaps in the story. 
Speaking of that story, I feel as though it's become a little bit too cluttered. Now that the previous three games have set up the arcs for the 8 primary characters, it feels as though many of the plot points are rushed along as though they were trying to get from one CG to the next rather than progressing the story. it also has a bad habit of requiring each one of the 6 cat girls have an individual comment on something over and over that don't really mean anything, just trying to juggle them into scenes where they don't really need to say anything, or could say something more interesting but simply don't. It feels rather forced. 
The only time anything that could count as interesting happens is when, during one point of the game, they break up from their overly ridged pairs to spend just a tiny bit of time with one of their other sisters. The main character commented on how strange it is too, bringing the feeling of non interaction to the for front. It's really quite sad that they didn't get the chance to branch out with their own family. 

All and all, there's a lot to love about the game, for sure. It's the same nekopara brand super cutsie stuff. The story as taken a step back, which is hard to ignore with all the potential they have now

86623801.review:
This game saved my life.

I am 47.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game an hour or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

85734432.review:
This is, without a doubt, the best visual novel in this series. I was looking forward to it's release and replayed the previous games to catch myself up on the story. This one was different, in a good way.

They tried different things in this visual novel, that I was not sure of when I first started it, but by the end, I thoroughly enjoyed the change of pace. So many new characters to learn of and react to, as well as actually seeing Kashou interact with them in more complex ways. It felt more immersive as a story. No spoilers here, but you really should play the game to find out what I mean here. The story is, by far, the best one of the series.

They also used a different art style it looks like. At least slightly, I sort of notice small differences compared to the previous games, but again it was questionable at first but I grew to like it. The more detailed animations, like cat ears perking or drooping as they speak, as well as it seemed the drawings were more detailed and seemed to pop more. I think I have to praise them for all the things they tried different that really just worked. Plenty of 'content' for you as well, 5 scenes!

It was adorable, cute and calming. I played it about an hour a night before I fell asleep and it didn't fail to put a smile on my face. This whole series is pretty damn good to me, and I look forward to new installments. I think this might be the best visual novel I've played so far, as I play more of them. No matter how many I play, I'm sure this one will stay close to me, however. 9/10!

85325048.review:
I've done one for Volume 1, Volume 2, and Extra, there's no way I'm passing up making a review on the latest and possibly greatest volume in the series. While I know people love to meme on these games for their "love" and "affection," the story of the catgirls of La Soleil is absolutely solid.

Before I praise the game, let me just go over some of the things that I didn't like or was disappointed in. Whenever I write for games / novels like this, I try to be as neutral as possible as well as looking beyond just the "artwork," which is actually where point number one comes in.

At first, I was not fond of the art style compared to the previous games. The thin lines and shiny features were a little straining on the eyes. Eventually, it grew on me that it became almost nostalgic in that if I see the style again, it would be immediately recognizable among the many other titles that line the store front. Some of the characters could have used a little polishing up, but otherwise everyone and everything look great.

Music, why are they re-using a lot of it? They've had 3/4ths of these tracks since the beginning, you could have done something different or experimental. There were so many missed opportunities to really set a scene with something more personal and instead we have Neko Neko or whatever track it is whenever they have the low sides and the bouncy notes of the cheerful parties.

So, that's about it for the cons, the positive of this recent release was the story and E-Mote system, both of which are just straight fantastic. Every character is shaped wonderfully to the point that I actually missed Cinnamon's stupid behavior because it was so unlike her to be that mature. You can tell the growth all of them have made over the past volumes and the throwbacks make it all the more memorable.

While I can't really recommend Volume 0, 1, and Extra, this is definitely worth picking up if you want something to read for a bit for those of you that might not have time for anime otherwise. I would not put it in the ranks of Clannad or Violet Evergarden, this is probably as good as Chobits or Ouran High School Host Club. At $10 USD, it's almost a steal for what you get out of this.

Unless you're looking for the special scenes, then probably might be too much.

All in all, I hold this series as a classic among visual novels and highly recommend you reading at least one of them, hopefully this one since it shows just how amazing one of these can be.

As a story, I was surprised with this one.  While I may have been... distracted, I still feel as if I should've been able to call some of the twists.  Even still, it was surprisingly touching, even if it lost the "self-insert" factor in favor of being able to tell a story after having worked through the main cast; no new cat girls means the MC actually gets a little bit of something

As a... "product" after installing the patch, it's significantly improved compared to the other entries.  There's now some animations!  It's a little front and backend loaded, pun intended, but having it being done so otherwise in service to the actual story would've just made somethings a little too crass; it doesn't feel as gross even as fantasy fulfillment this go around!

Having experienced the game without the patch currently not offered here on Steam, I can confidently say that while it's seamless enough, you're really not getting the same experience.  Anyone thinking with their head that's on their shoulders can easily spot where the saucier things would've been with enough things in the regular dialogue to directly suggest what happens.  So I really couldn't recommend, in good faith, that you play this game in its censored, Steam state, and as the fourth entry in this series of scandalous fantasy I'm not sure how or why you'd want to experience it in any other way

On the plus, you do have the option to skip the creamy bits even with the patch with the composed prompt of if there's people around you or not, so don't feel as if having the patch will instantly sentence you into some kind of purgatory if you have sudden company while experience the story

83877405.review:
Muestra el panorama socio-político de la sociedad occidental y específicamente, la sociedad española, en nuestra historia contemporánea y tanto sus consecuencias socio-económicas, como socio-políticas.


El juego tiene un trasfondo contexto histórico-social muy definido por la guerra carlista que inició en el tercer año de la tercera década del siglo 19 en el contexto histórico ibérico. Dicha guerra asentó las bases a la Guerra Civil del 36 que convocó en una guerra de dos bandos; en una dictadura con algunas características fascistas denominando en un nuevo tipo de ideología totalitaria autodenominada "democracia orgánica" derivante; el franquismo. No solo eso, sino que posteriormente hubo una serie de golpes de estados previos republicanos al propio franquismo, en el que se ejerció violencia contra toda institución relacionada con la eclesiología española, disidentes e inclusive; dentro de la violencia, la quema de los edificios religiosos. Dictadura procedente del bando ganador, que duró unos 36 años con algunos percances previos igualmente anti-democráticos republicanos y procedente de una división social, concluyendo en que la bondad en los dos bandos era inexistente, no existiendo lado bueno.
45 años después de una dictadura de represión de libertades y derechos fundamentales, pero con una economía nada despreciable entre la octava y novena potencia mundial, con una hambruna casi inexistente, solo hablando en términos relacionados a la situación social o en cuanto a libertades y/o derechos fundamentales se refiere; era reprochable.
Este juego muestra como, el programa de "la mili", la milicia española obligatoria a varones durante la represión franquista, era diseñado. Es decir, recuerda a esas órdenes del gobierno franquista para la realización y la práctica de tiro en el campo de batalla.

E de decir que este entretenimiento audiovisual lo eh disfrutado con el parche +18, si usted posee la posibilidad de jugarlo de la misma forma que lo disfrute yo, lo recomiendo. valió cada maldito segundo

Thanks for helping, NekoPara.

83264446.review:
[h1]TL;DR: It is Nekopara. And it has a new cute catgirl, and cakes. As Gwen Stefani used to say, ‘What you waiting for?!’[/h1]

I think everyone and their grandma have already heard about Nekopara series – most probably even both the anime and the games [i](the latter being more popular for, khm, reasons)[/i]. This winter NEKO WORKs decided to bring us even more happiness with the fourth volume of this kawaii masterwork full of sugar and spice and everything deliciously nice. But should you buy it? Well, let me tell you why ‘yes, yes and once again yes’ is the only possible answer here!

This is my last review in 2020 (unless the muse visits me out of nowhere again, as she really likes doing), so I decided to finish this year on a positive note. And what can be more wholesome and sweeter than cute catgirls? Only catgirls with confectionary!

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2336601251

[h1]Welcome Back, Master[/h1]

Ah, Nekopara. When I played the first game many years ago, my heart was caught immediately by the amazing artwork. Not even because it was fully animated – and this was my first novel with such a quality of visuals, mind you - but because of how beautifully drawn everything was. From girls’ designs of various shapes and colors, to their bright uniforms that really make the atmosphere of the café even sweeter, to the marvelous cakes that are forms of art on their own. And this has not changed through the whole series, which is a huge plus. The artist who worked and continues working on these projects deserves an award, and you cannot change my mind. There is a huge amount of beautiful CGs. And the pictures of food…ah, be still my heart!

Visuals aside, what else does the fourth volume offer? The previous ones had very wholesome stories with fun humor, occasional innuendo [i](brought to you by Cinnamon mostly; thank her for this later)[/i] and real drama about people’s relationships and hardships. This world full of catpanions might look sweet at the first glance, but it has its dark moments too. The good thing is that all Nekopara games do not focus on them and prefer to show characters overcoming their insecurities and achieving their dreams – which is exactly what we need this year and any other time, to be honest.

But returning to the question about the volume four specifically. This particular title introduces us to Kashou’s (the protagonist) story before La Soleil (I think it was partially mentioned in the third volume too) and how he got his passion for Western-style cakes instead of the traditional Japanese confectionary that his family is famous for. We will also learn more about his relationships with other family members. Another important part is that we can finally meet Kashou’s famous teacher who was only mentioned before! All in all, the fourth volume is very emotional and, I will be honest here, it made me cry several times. There is the usual fun and bubbly atmosphere too, but the game does not shy away from some more serious topics – finding yourself, connections between generations, doing what you really love and following your heart. This is something that we have to face almost every day, so do not get fooled by people who say that Nekopara is just about fanservice. It is a well-written story that is not something stellar or groundbreaking, but still very heartwarming and relatable. Sometimes slice-of-live genre with catgirls and cakes is exactly what you need to feel better.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2336600930

Another winning point of this game is the voice acting. Each catgirl has her own unique manner of speaking, and all of their lines are fully voiced. And the same goes even for small background characters! Kashou is the only one who does not say a word through all games, but it is a pretty traditional thing for visual novels. Also, the opening and ending songs are really good, as always.

The only drawback I can think of is that all Nekopara games are pretty short – just about 5-6 hours. As they say, good things never last, sadly. At the same time, I think that fourth volume, the same as its sisters before, does not overstay its welcome and gives us just enough emotions and feelings to get attached to both characters and the story. Better have a short but fun and lovable game rather than a long but boring behemoth with overused tropes and jokes, right? Also, you will sometimes notice occasional typos or a bit strange translation [i](did Vanilla really say ‘cute AF’???)[/i], but there are very few of them.

And a small note before we move on to the last part of this review: if you check the settings, you can see a curious option called “Chest Bounciness”. I think Nekopara has reached the levels of fanservice never thought possible before – not something that I pay much attention too, but fans of such things will definitely appreciate this feature. Oh, and do not forget that you can actually pet all catgirls, and even Shigure and other characters, and listen to the cute noises they make.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2336812957

[h1]We Hope To See You Back Again, Master[/h1]

If you want to treat yourself for Christmas and New Year, NEKOPARA Vol. 4 will be a great purchase – a pretty big part of the story is dedicated to winter holidays, after all. It gives more light to Kashou himself and his dreams this time, which makes his personality even more developed. We also get some quality time with his sister Shigure, a completely new French catgirl and popular Japanese activities such as scenes in hit springs, for example. The Steam version does not have any 18+ content – everything has been carefully removed, - and features only occasional references, so it should be a safe read (not for children, though, of course). Though Shigure needs to chill a bit. Or even not a bit…

Oh, and I have almost forgotten! We will meet some characters from previous games and relive memories of the past. The fourth volume is where everything comes together to make the story even more complete.

To sum up, NEKO WORKs made us an amazing holiday present in the form of yet another lovely chapter in Nekopara story. Both fans of the series and new players will enjoy it a lot, and the game helps you create just the right atmosphere to enjoy yourself. Need distraction from hard working days and daily routine? Nekopara once again comes to the rescue!  

[i]P.S. I am not usually the one to ask for anything, but this year has been a really difficult and exhausting one for me. So, it would be really sweet of you if you could come to my profile before the New Year and write something nice either there or under the main illustration – I have specifically decorated it in Nekopara style to bring some sunshine and make people smile when they visit me, even if a little bit. Wish everyone great holidays! Cheers! 💖[/i]

82860591.review:
[h1][u][b] NEKOPARA Vol. 4 Krazy Review! [/b][/u][/h1]
[h1][u]Introduction [/u][/h1]
Well here it is the game we've been waiting for since Vol. 3 released in 2017. And oh boy what a masterpiece of a game it is. Sayori, you are a legend. I'm so glad that you were willing to make Vol. 4 it blew any of my expectations out of the window and I absolutely loved it. As with my review of Vol. 1 I'm going to go into detail about this game so SPOILERS AHEAD for not only Vol. 4 but the other NEKOPARA volumes too.

[h1][u] 18+ DLC [/u][/h1]
Where to start? I'd recommend you get the 18+ DLC from DLSite or Denpasoft for the Steam release as the game isn't the same without it. Example: the beginning of the game is different depending on whether you have the DLC or not. If you do have the DLC then some options will appear before the 18+ scenes those options are.
1. There are other people around you.
and
2. There is no one around you.
These options are actually questions to the player. If you have other people around you whilst you're playing and you don't want them to see NSFW content then click option 1. If you simply don't care or you're alone click option 2. However I do recommend that you go back later and make sure to click both as they both show different CGs and you'll love what happens either way.

With the 18+ DLC is these scenes:
[spoiler]Scene 1 - Chocola and Vanilla (w/ Kashou)
 Scene 2 - Coconut and Azuki (w/ Kashou)
 Scene 3 - Maple and Cinnamon (w/ Kashou)
 Scene 4 - Chocola and Vanilla (NO Kashou)
 Scene 5 - Harem (all catgirls):
 Chocola, Coconut and Cinnamon
 Azuki, Maple and Vanilla
 then one each.
[/spoiler]

[h1][u] STORY! [/u][/h1]
[b][u] SPOILERS AHEAD [/u][/b]
[spoiler] Anyway onto the story. Vol. 4 starts after the events of NEKOPARA Vol. 3 which means that all 6 catgirls are Kashou's catpanions. This story takes place about a month before Christmas (so November) and follows Kashou as he aims to impress his father who is disappointed in him. He goes to a hot spring with the catgirls to relax a bit and take time off his work. After returning from the hot springs, he decides to go to Paris (France) to meet his mentor and get more help. After returning from France, he enjoys Christmas at La Soleil where we see a brief appearance from Milk. He then has a Christmas party at home with the whole Minaduki family. At the end, Shigure moves into La Soleil with the rest of the catgirls and we prepare ourselves for Vol. 5. [/spoiler]

[h1][u] My Thoughts [/u][/h1]
Well what can I say? I've been waiting for Vol. 4 for a long time and after being "somewhat satisfied" with the TV anime, I was looking forward to seeing a sequel to Vol. 3. In my opinion the story continues smoothly and the game in general is more about Kashou as the main character instead of the catgirls. His trip to France was really nice and getting to see Beignet and Fraise was awesome. I cannot wait to see them in Vol. 5. I was quite disappointed, personally, with the very small amount of time we saw Milk but I'm still glad she was included as adult Milk looks awesome. If I don't watch out then Milk might become my favourite neko (just kidding, ChocoVani forever!).

So is NEKOPARA Vol. 4 worth the money? Definitely! This game is much longer than any of the previous ones and even without the 18+ DLC the story made me cry a lot. Of course with the 18+ DLC OH MY I loved it. It was worth the extra money for it. I actually bought this game on Steam (18+ DLC on DLSite) but I also purchased a physical copy and the R-18 Artbook is superb and so I'm waiting for the digital release of the artbook if that happens.

As a NEKOPARA Collector I can safely say that Vol.4 is equivalent to Avengers End Game. In the sense of: End Game is a great film if you've seen the other Marvel films beforehand. Same with Vol. 4, it's a great game if you've played the other games beforehand. However, even as a standalone it's a good volume to purchase. I'm glad I added this game to my collection and I also purchased the Switch version too.

Well for now that's my review of Vol. 4. If I come up with anything to add to it then I'll edit this review accordingly.
Sorry for making this another long review but I felt like Vol. 4 deserved it. Thank you Sayori, NEKOWORKs and anyone else who worked on Vol. 4, you've made me so happy. HERE'S TO VOL. 5!

https://store.steampowered.com/app/1406990/NEKOPARA_Vol_4/

82814341.review:
Nekopara may singlehandedly be the greatest game I have ever played. Thus far, I have 100% completion on Volume 1, Volume 2, Volume 3, and at time of writing, I am nearly done with Volume 4. I do not plan on playing Volume Extra nor Volume 0 because those ones are weird. However, the main sequence of games is absolutely fantastic; the art style, the characters, the soundtrack, and the flow of the story.

Firstly, as aformetioned, the art style is fantastic. The colors beautifully flow in a simplistic yet elegant design, painting each background with basic, yet noticeable prop design- from the beach to the cafe itself, each scene has been masterfully crafted by possibly the most talented graphic designers the world has to offer. I was so immersed that when watching the sunset in Volume 1, I truly felt like I was there on the boardwalk myself.

The music is one of my favourite parts of Nekopara. The slick drum beats, with upbeat rhythms and melody that kisses the ears like a prostitute being paid triple digits. In the main menu, the sequence of notes that plays is so insanely catchy that I've contemplated installing it into a speaker and playing it 24/7 around my house. During the sad moments, the elegant sounds of piano are as if Mozart himself is jerking off the composer under the desk; I've never been so touched by any musical piece in my life to this extent.

The characters are easily the greatest part of Nekopara. Each one has their own personality, aspirations, goals, and morals; it makes them feel incredibly fleshed out and real and not part of a linear propset for the player to toy around with. For example, at first glance, Maple's story arc seems to just be a white girl art vsco hoe, but once you delve into Chapter 4 of Volume 3, you realize her desire to perform musically has been running back to since she was first adopted alongside with Cinnamon. Even moreso, I found Azuki's story arc to be the most enjoyable as it displayed her rough-around-the-edges attitude to simply be a ploy to contain the respect of her younger sisters, due to her insecurities from being physically smaller than them.

At first glance, the story was the weakest part of the games. However, once you play through a satisfactory amount, you realize that it's incredibly deep and touching with lore that reaches out to the furthest realms. On a surface level, Kashou is merely a patissier who is trying to replicate his own mentor's style when baking pastries, running a harem of catgirls on the side. Though, especially in Volume 4, you realize that his relationship with his father's own Japanese style of baking and his own Western adaptations tend to clash, thus causing problems in the household. This is what inevitably leads to Kashou leaving the house and opening his cafe, which really exemplifies the pathos of the character.

In conclusion, I would recommend this game series to anyone with time to spend for a heart-touching story about a family who uses the cafe to bring themselves closer to one another. In one word, it is perfection.

82709364.review:
I'd been waiting for vol4 to come out for probably a year since finishing vol3. At the time, I said, " I have complete confidence that Volume 4 will maintain this level of Excellence" and I was not disappointed. Nekopara is one of those rare gems that is always amazing no matter how many times you replay it. And as always, getting the adult patch isn't required, but adds a level of character depth that I would NOT recommend passing up on. Though the addition of the "alone, not alone" story path divergence for the adult scenes did surprise me. Whole other story paths were created AND voiced! The creators definitely put in the effort and impressed me, that's for sure. The side paths are shorter, but also fun to travel down, so I would recommend taking them at least once... especially since it's required to unlock all the scenes in the extras gallery.

The animation is as stunning and beautiful as ever, and you can feel the emotion from the VA's as if you were there yourself. Plus the background audio really adds to the depth of the game to pull you into it.

The story itself is nothing short of spectacular. Each volume has gotten better and better, and vol4 is no exception. This time, we get to dig into the Minaduki family history and see how everything got to this point. Even Kashou and Shigure's Mother and Father have major rolls as well. We get a trip to France to the original "La Soleil" and get introduced to Kashou's mentor that he trained with, when he travelled overseas. Everything unfolds as Kashou returns to his roots in search of expert advise. There's even a reunion between him and a catgirl in France, named "Fraise" and the return of the catgirl "Milk" who has grown quite a bit since her last appearance. You can feel the struggles and triumphs of all of them as Chocola, Vanilla, Azuki, Coconut, Maple, Cinnamon, and even Shigure, try their best to help Kashou out in his time of self doubt... as well as reaffirm their relationships and how they feel about him and each other.

There are a few points that are left up in the air, regarding family relations (no spoilers) So I'm hoping this means that a vol5 is already in production or at least in the planning stages.

The Nekopara franchise now includes: Nekopara Vol1, Nekopara Vol0, Nekopara Extra, Nekopara OVA Extra, Nekopara Vol2, Nekopara Vol3, Nekopara Vol4, Nekopara OVA(based on Vol1), Nekopara Anime(12 episodes), and even the "NekoPaLIVE" VR Concert.

So while I pray for a Nekopara Vol 5, and hope to see the 12 episode anime get a bluray/dvd release soon(no funimation edits please, video OR audio), I can't help but think that the end of Vol4 makes a perfect spot for a complete collectors edition release. One that has all 6 games +DLC, both OVAs, the 12episode anime, and extra disks for ALL opening/ending videos and soundtracks. oh and all the large print full color artbooks too!
[obvious suggestion to the creators] I mean, all those physical copies would surely be worth a small fortune [hint hint] LOL

So yeah. Vol4 is an awesome continuation to an already awesome franchise, and leaves an opening for even more titles that I hope the creators intend to take full advantage of. The "Nekopara Universe" is in desperate need of expansion, and personally I pray that it will never end !!!

81871968.review:
[h2]NekoPara 4[/h2]
[i]Catgirl diabetes returns![/i]

[h3]Preclaimer[/h3]
- This is an Adult Visual Novel (DLC obtainable at Denpasoft), designed to be R18, which is why I consider the R18 content part of the whole and will include it in this review. If for whatever reason you are not interested in this content or aren't legally allowed to play it, you should just skip the R18 section of this review.
- Since many Visual Novels are similar in a bunch of ways, I'm gonna review this one on a few common aspects, heavily referencing previous NekoPara titles.

[hr]
[h3]Chronology[/h3]
The order I personally recommend the games to be played in, though 1→2→3→4 should be obvious, the rest is optional.
[list][*][url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/0256667/recommended/333600/]NekoPara Vol.1[/url]
[*][i]NekoPara Vol.0 (1h long SoL FanDisc)[/i]
[*][url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/0256667/recommended/420110/]NekoPara Vol.2[/url]
[*][url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/0256667/recommended/602520/]NekoPara Vol.3[/url]
[*][i]NekoPara Extra (2h long SoL bonus from the catgirls' childhood)[/i]
[*]NekoPara Vol.4 ←[/list]

[hr]
[h3]Graphical & Technical Quality[/h3]
Welcome to the future of Live2D onscreen nekos! With this now being the fourth part of same series, you probably know what you should be able to expect. We get all the quality that was already packed with Vol.3, and make it even better!

But what does that mean exactly?
Well, first and foremost - NekoPara Vol.4 actually is developed in 1080p! Enjoying cute, fictional catgirls doing cute stuff never looked so clean before.

Other than that, the CG artworks - which are a lot more - look even better, the Live2D animation of the characters is even more lively/detailed (even though the level of sound responsive lip syncing is both simplistic and well crafted at the same time) and the headpatting minigame accompanies us again with more variety to it.

On the tech side it seems Vol.4 reverts to a more "default" KiriKiri Engine version, which means our good old, hidden "advanced settings menu" is back  the way we know and love it. We also get a seperate "choose language" screen on the first startup and the "scene/chapter transition" screens don't autoplay anymore, giving you all the time to enjoy (or screenshot) the imagery and read the texts on them.

The overall translated dialogue gets a new level of quality as well, with more naturally feeling slang at some points and all that, though of course there are one or two textual errors here and there - nothing too fancy.

But the probably most important new feature of Vol.4: Pseudo Choices!
...though this is something for a different section of this review.

[hr]
[url]https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2313665781[/url]

[hr]
[h3]Content & Runtime[/h3]
What can we expect from NekoPara Vol.4?
Going down the path Vol.3 went even further, Vol.4 now features a serious story. Of course there are enough simple and silly slice of life moments featuring cute catgirls doing cute things, though we have a serious major storyline going all throughout the game and offering lots and lots of background information on the protagonist and his family.
Minor spoiler alert ---but since the protagonist travels to france, we even get a free lecture on cultural differences from the Japanese point of view - fancy. ---

The gallery, unlocked the moment you have at least one thing to view there, enables us to re-view, re-watch and re-enjoy the [b]78 CGs[/b], 14 SDs and 26 OSTs (mostly the usual, but a few new tracks as well), the opening and ending movie and all the "scenes" once we encountered them before ingame.

And another major benefit - we get more for the same price! NekoPara Vol.4 still is a linear Visual Novel and hence rather short (compared to similarily priced Multi Route VNs), but it actually is longer, summing up to around 15+h of content (not rush-skipping) [partly due to the "need" to backtrack and rewatch certain scenes], split across 5+1 chapters.

[hr]
[url]https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2313660753[/url]

[hr]
[h3]The R18 Content[/h3]
Oi, what would NekoPara be without impressive and high quality H-content?
And so, what is a NekoPara with more impressive and higher quality H-content? Right - awesome!

Vol.4 goes yet again all out, stepping up (and at some points even positively down) from what we know from the predecessor(s).
There are 5 H-Scenes in total, one per chapter.
All of those have animated parts. Yes, they are still GIF loop animated most of the part, but they actually have variety and transitions, making them full fledged GIF loop "animations" with beginning and end.

Sadly we don't have background moaning anymore, though we get a cool new set of less annoyingly used sound effects.

When it comes to the depiction of bodily fluids, the inhuman stamina of the actors or the overall intensity of the action - it's NekoPara, duh. Though, probably due to the amount and length of the H-Scenes, it sometimes seems more... humane then before. Except for the long anticipated sixsome finale.
When it comes to fetishes, Vol.4 tries itself on some backdoor poking and foot worshipping - but ey, the peeing fetish is gone!

Of course the game still is [b]mosaic censored[/b], but eh, whatever. Oh yeah, and that weird steam sided auto censoring on screenshots and streams is still there, even with the off-site DLC.

But now the important part. I said Vol.4 offers pseudo choices. Well, yes, here they are - every H-Scenes is preceded by a choice, asking you if you are alone right now or not. That way you can freely watch the R16 version of the "intimate" scenes to your liking even with the R18 version. (You probably even need to when you want ALL the juicy CGs unlocked, hence backtracking, hence a longer playtime.)

The question now... Why buy the R18 DLC when not even using it?
Good question. But let's look at it that way:
Since there are normal, different R16 versions of the intimate scenes that didn't just get the R18 stuff forcefully cut out - [b]I can even fully recommend Vol.4 without R18 DLC[/b].

[hr]
[url]https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2313656170[/url]

[hr]
[h3]Conclusion[/h3]
Is this game worth it?
Yes.
...
What, you need more arguments? I sure didn't, and probably noone who enjoyed the first 3 (to 5) parts too. And if you didn't YET - just get the whole bundle and enjoy yourself!
The next sale is always around the corner.

I'm normally not a review-writer but i felt the need to just say: Thank you. Many visual novels focus very strongly on being...well...lewd. Which is of cause nothing wrong, don't misunderstand me. We all have needs to pleasure in some way.

Thanks to everyone who was involved in creating this, I hope you go on with these games.

PRE-COMPLETION REVIEW:
I can't help it, I'm writing yet another review for the latest installment of the Nekopara series. I've been a fan of it since I first stumbled upon Nekopara's demo one late evening and played through. I bought it for myself and then friend that I bicker with it later. Then I found out about the patch that you could download for it. Since that fateful night, I've been a follower of this franchise. 

Currently, this is much longer than the last games, which shows that the game is indeed expanding, and despite you already having an incredibly close relationship with everyone you know, the game builds on that foundation. I am...displeased with myself for being this addicted to the game, but it truly is a joy everytime! 

If you're wondering whether or not to get this game and you've completed the the others...Stop. Buy it. It's worth it! Just like Vol.3, I started this game with the 18+ patch (that I totally bought and didn't pirate.) and I must admit, this doesn't pull any punches when it gives the reader what they want from the very beginning. Though, if you are more a fluff person, the non-adult interactions are truly adorable.

I have put 3 hours into the game, mostly because of the extended scenes (#TingleFeels) are waaay long, but I don't have any regrets, because like the rest in the series, the animation is suuuper smooth and oddly satisfying to watch. Call me what you want, I like it.

So far, it's a 10/10 outta me.
