Another amazing game and well worth the wait for it's release.
The story is engaging as always and this one did the same thing that NekoPara 0 and Extra did, where they filled in some story questions that many people probably wanted to know. Such as meeting his parents, or where in France he studies abroad and with who. 
I won't go into to much detail for those wishing not to have spoilers, but I can say like the rest they have really done the story well and answered more of the questions people probably had through the first few games. With a touch of main character soul searching/self discovery on the path to becoming the best he can be.

(Side Note)
At the time of this review many people would probably have a slight issue with no 18+ steam patch, trying to go through different websites and other hoops to get the file that allows those extra scenes since like many other sites... Valve cares more on appearances then the full supporting fanbase that is paying them. Or in other words being huffy and for the moment at least not letting the DLC patch allowed through, hopefully in future this changes but hey we can only see what happens.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Overall though this was a great game, the characters emotions come across well and the story is great just like the others. Regardless of people complaining about the issue above, I say 100% buy this game and give it a go as it is worth every penny. Besides if your playing this game there is a high chance you already played at least NekoPara's 1-3 so just sit back and enjoy the story.

81044424.review: Motivation. Regret. Discovery. These are just a few things that you discover within Nekopara Vol. 4. Putting aside all the memes and adult content for now, the Nekopara franchise has evolved a lot, and this entry in the series deepens the understanding of the universe of Nekopara to another level. We discover that Kashou's family isn't as pristine as he would like it to be, owing to his divergent ideas, and over the course of the game, we see those three themes develop. From a lost patissier, Kashou rediscovers why he truly became a pastry chef, and why he and his father clashed. We discover not only this, but also his mentor, and how her tutelage has enabled Kashou to become the patissier he is today. But between these events, we also see a new connection - a new discovery of how things really are. The story is well written - this isn't just an adult game series anymore - this is a well written visual novel that also has some of the best adult content, not the other way around. This is a satisfying game, whether playing it with the adult content or not. A high recommendation.

81017836.review:
Compared to the original series, it's had such a major overhaul that you could call it a remaster. To name a couple of things I wanna point out, firstly, the (main) characters' details are astounding, simulating lighting and raytracing in real time while keeping the character models not too oversaturated and shiny. Furthermore, the story as a visual novel has had many elements to give the dialogues more natural feelings (such as character reactions to each other's conversations in real time).
Lastly, despite being a slice of life series, a genre that's usually underappreciated and maybe shunned by cultured intellectual weebs and chads alike, the level of details combined with the Nekopara series' unique mix of comedy and drama throughout really makes the experience enjoyable and relaxing.
One more thing that I forgot to mention: the soundtrack. As 7-8/10 as the ol' classics are, not much has changed. And honestly, I can't tell if the same songs being used again scene after scene is a blessing or a curse. Nevertheless, the new ones ain't so bad, 7-7.5/10. Personal fav? Nyanko to Bansan.
That being said, *because* it's a slice of life, you can indulge in the mishaps and goofiness of it completely braindead and pay no heeds to deep stuff (no pun intended), and that's fine. However, if you're someone who can only appreciate better quality-of-life types of visual novels, this 4th installment of the Nekopara series is highly recommended.




Heads up to anyone getting their hands on the 18+ patch for the 1st time (which I totally didn't pirate), there's a threesome right at the beginning. And a lil' something at the end, whose image will burn into your eyes, soul and 20 other body parts that you might not recognize. Just lettin' ya know.

80808656.review:
Well, I've been waiting for this game for almost two years. And what can I say after so much waiting time? 

Part of EXTRA showed us that even with a stranger, you can become a real family if you just trust each other. 

Part 0 showed us, in fact, the ideal family of the main character, why the ideal? Not because they don't have conflicts or anything, no. Because they value catgirls as their family. People in this family consider catgirls equal to themselves, and worthy to be called people. This part showed that it is important to respect not only your family or your elders, but it is important to respect the people you do not know as much. 

Part 1 taught us how important it is to learn something new, even what seems impossible to learn. 

Part 2 taught us how important it is to be able to forgive, because even if you and the other person, seemingly already hating each other after a quarrel, you need to remember that talking to each other can be reconciled and even become best friends. 

Part 3 taught us the pursuit of the dream, taught us that every dream can be realized if we do our best to do so. 

What does part 4 teach us? 
-respect and love for elders, teachers, family, parents. 

Part 4 teaches us that we cannot reach heights without the help of the older generation, without their help and their long-life experience. 

Already for 6 parts, this game shows us that even catgirls who are not in fact people (In the world of this game) are trying to become them, they have important human qualities that we humans don't have. They are constantly learning something new, are able to forgive,  stream to the dream, be able to trust strangers, and respect other people. 

Do you still think that all the parts of this game are "just a cute game with catgirls"? Think again, maybe this game will teach you to forgive, strive for a dream, respect other people and strive to learn something new, perhaps this game will teach you how to be human.

80746354.review:
やっと... 

Nekopara Volume 4 is what the series has been leading up to for six long years. We've got it all and more in this installment. Six cats weren't enough, so they added a seventh. The story is refreshing and well paced. Comedy is fun. The e-mote system is incredible. The music is great. The art is top notch and the game is of respectable length and feels very full. Nekoworks took risks, and as a result the game feels like a very new experience instead of "more of the same".

Story and Characters:

Since the mane six have already been in focus in previous installments, the game instead concentrates on carving depth in the established characters. Much of the story is dedicated to the accumulation of Cashew's own troubles, which grounds him a lot more than in the previous games (I'm glad they didn't keep him a faceless self-insert).

The character growth is accomplished by the story, which tries (and largely is successful) in being more intimate and serious than previous entries. I think the series needed a change of pace like this. More of the same would have been fine, but seeing characters deal with new and unexpected situations kept me interested a lot more than I thought I would. The story never stays in one spot too long, and explores a pretty broad set of locations and experiences.

Character writing breaks a lot of arbitrary barriers that seemed to have been imposed in the previous entries. No longer is everyone (just) a walking, meowing trope. Interaction between characters has also been improved greatly, with a lot of dynamics that haven't been done before. I'm sure it was intentional to drip-feed us that kind of thing, but I welcome it regardless because it's a really big improvement. I appreciate the characters' actual character a lot more this time around.

New characters, including several people and one cat, are welcome additions that support the story well. I love Fraise very much, but I think the stars of the show were the humans added to the story. Seeing fully drawn and animated people is a new for the series and serves to make the game feel a lot less empty. They're written pretty well and contribute to an overall better sense of immersion.

Sometimes, the story and some characters become predictable. I expected that, but if you didn't, 🤡. However, the story overall is a big step forward in so many ways for the franchise. I was expecting to kind of trudge through this story, but I was very pleasantly surprised.


TN and Localization:

I probably know about as much Japanese as you, so I can't really provide insight to the faithfulness or compare the English translation to the source material. However, I can say that they did a really good job at making the script feel cohesive. It felt like it was written in English from the start, which is impressive.

The use of more advanced puns and clever wordage kept me cracking smiles throughout my time. The Japanese vocals were great too, per my expectations.

I haven't read a ton of VN's, but I think they did a fantastic job here. This writing and TN has raised my standards for both translated VN's and native English VN writing.


Visuals:

Nekopara has always been known for its e-mote system, which has its characters moving and bouncing around the screen with scripted realism not usually seen in the industry. I'm so happy that they haven't stopped improving in this regard. Their e-mote system is evolved and more incredible than ever. A couple of things I've noticed:

- Characters react at any time to what others are saying, mid-sentence.
- Characters can change their posture, move their head, change facial emotes, and physically move many times in a single voice-line. Previously, it was pretty much one big change per line.
- Characters have be featured in a cute mini-window near the text-box, with full e-mote capabilities.
- Characters can now wiggle uncontrollably
- Improved ear movements

The developers have done a great job making use of these improvements to e-mote, allowing for incredible expression. It's clear that so much more time and love had to go into each line to make the most of these new features.

Beyond that, there is more variety for each character, from expressions to poses to character-specific animations.

The game finally outputs at 1080p natively (i would have preferred 1440p or higher🙃). This allows for the models and backgrounds to look a lot better overall, as you could imagine. This is a huge jump from 720p, thank god. "pre-rendered" CG in motion is a lot less compressed, too. 

Sayori's art style continues to evolve with this game. Forgive my lack of knowledge in this area, but I think the more shiny and lighted shading is really nice once you get accustomed to looking at it. I understand it may not be everyone's cup of tea, but change is nice (especially when you're on the sixth game). She's clearly moving out of her old comfort zone with new perspectives, subjects and angles with each still. Speaking of stills, they're plentiful and very nice, per usual.


As a Game / VN:

Nekopara remains kinetic, for better and worse. I don't have to worry about messing shit up all the god damn time (that's what real life is for, right), but then you don't feel quite as involved as you do in other VNs. This also results in a very polished, yet not really re-playable game. That's just the series at this point though. If you were okay with it before, you'll be fine with it now.

The UI has seen a pretty nice facelift (i bet they did it because they had to re-do everything for 1080p rendering anyways). I really, REALLY like how the current text blends perfectly into the backlog as you turn it on (before, it would awkwardly shift an inch upwards and not wrap the same way). The UI also benefits from the higher resolution, making it look less blurry overall.

The game runs at 60fps, and by not being exclusive fullscreen, the mouse will always look like your monitor's refresh rate. The game can be swapped to windowed mode really easily, and scales as well as it possibly could, supporting native Windows re-size. There are no fancy upscaling options for beyond 1080p (it just does some bicubic shit or something) which would have been cool, but I didn't expect that.

We've got like 10 pages of saves with a bunch on each page, and the thumbnails are nice and will even show up when you hover over "quick load" ingame.

The controls aren't changable, but are about what you'd expect. The hotkeys are responsive, as always. The settings has nice audio and language settings. You can set the bounciness. The Gallery and Music Player are pretty cool. Sucks that the music goes back to the main theme when you return to the main menu though, but maybe that's just me.


As a XXX:

Gotta buy it from elsewhere, which one might think is weird because the older games have received such DLC on Steam now. However, I respect Nekoworks supporting their original distributor of such content and making it exclusive to them. Hate it? can always use google.

There's now an option to go for the SFW scene (which are now very fleshed out instead of being silly cuts) before each encounter. I like this :)

The scenes are as technically advanced as the rest of the game. I think they've done a better job at making them less awkward, especially with the dialog. The cats talk like themselves instead of just your average moaning motherfucker. They're a good bit sexier because of this, trust me.

Scenes are enjoyable and by god are they plentiful. They don't really get in the way of the story, and you'll go long stretches without them (in a good way). For the first time, it kind of feels like they were invested more in the rest of the game rather than making the rest of the game a vehicle for this stuff.


Overall:

I loved it. So cute, really hot, but not so shallow. If it continues, I'm hoping that the series continues to evolve in this fashion. Too many successful series settle and suffer from complacency nowadays

Vanilla: Contrasting with chocola's kind of submissive personality, she complement this with a more active and dominant personality, she seems carefree, like a normal cat nature, [spoiler] In her H scenes, You're gonna see her mostly accompanied from Chocola thanks to their close relationship, at first she seems more into Chocola than into MC but with the passing of the volumes, she looks really appreciative and in love with the MC as with Chocola, In the H scenes you can see her dominant and kind of sadistic(Not in all the extent of the word) personality (Like that scene with Azuki in Volume 2) as a side note, her voice in these scenes is ok, but imo chocola's is still better. [/spoiler]
Score: 8/10.

Coconut: Her personality contrasts pretty well with her physical appearance since she looks mature, but she's also one of the youngest Catgirls in the main cast, so her personality is more sweet, playful, ditzy and innocent; she seems that has been in love with MC from kind of a long time, [spoiler] In volume 2 she starts calling MC Onii-chan,  as Chocola's scenes, her H scenes are really sweet, her mature voice makes a great contrast with the innocent tone of what she says in these. the fact that she reffers to MC as Onii-chan and her mature voice makes a 9/10 H scenes wise. [/spoiler]
Side note: Heterochromia is a ++
Score: 8.5/10

[/spoiler]
Score: 7.7/10

Cinnamon: She's really into sex and perversion, has a really big chest and a mature voice, she really loves Maple and has a pretty close relationship with her, [spoiler] Her first H scene comes kind of late in Volume 3, but is very refreshing and innovative due to being a lesbian scene with Maple only, having a plot related background and bonding even more this relationship (Important fact to the next Volume). Her Scenes with MC are really lewd and noisy, so take care with the earphones, this makes the scenes better, tho. She has a real good scene in volume 4. [/spoiler]
Score: 9.5/10

Maple: She has kind of a serious and hime-ish personality at first, but with the pass of volume 3 and 4 you can really feel her character growth with a romantic personality directed to the MC, She cares a lot and does a great duo(Not only sexually related, but ye) with Cinnamon. [spoiler] In her H scenes she has that kind of behavior like "Oh no, we shouldn't be doing this" or "please don't do that" in a embarrased tone, but enjoying what is happening at the same time, which is a plus, personally, in these scenes you can really sense her romantic vibe. Cinnamon AND Maple: [spoiler] In volume 4 They state that they have sex regularly. [/spoiler]

80565257.review:
After a little over 100 hours It's definitely time for a proper review. As the sixth installment in the series one would think that the game play would dwindle or begin to be watered down, but in actuality the exact opposite has happened. 

I don't want to claim that I am the best, but I have spent a lot of time playing, more than most, and even with 100 hours I have come no where close to mastering this game, and nobody I know is close either. The skill cap alongside exhilarating game play is just an instant hook, and I simply have not been able to stop playing.

The soundtrack is top tier, up there with even AAA titles. Sound design is the same story. Characters are the same that we've all come to love yet they still don't get old and certain character arcs rival some of the most legendary arcs of other characters from other media IMHO.

A true gem in a sea of modern garbage. Game of the year without a doubt in my mind, perhaps game of the decade unless future installments continue to improve the formula.

80548573.review:
Been waiting a long time for this to come out, and was it worth the wait? God yes. Since vol 1, adored this series. It's hands-down my favourite VN series, and even all these years later that still holds true.

I admit I had some doubts as to what might happen in vol 4 given that Kashou had cemented his relationship with all 6 catgirls and their arcs were essentially done. Focusing on Kashou himself's arc was definately a good move, since raising further issues with the girls for him to resolve would have been just pushing it, at least in my opinion. Learning more about Kashou himself was certainly interesting, given his true motivations haven't always been clear. Vol 3 did make it somewhat clearer thanks to his interactions with Maple, but it was still a little vague.

And I admit, I was worried the focus might shift to Shigure. Which wouldn't have been an issue, except that it might lead to a 'deeper relationship' with her which I personally would have found kinda uncomfortable. Shigure's amusing, but pushing that too far would be a bit much. Which did lead to one issue with this volume, but I'll cover that later.

The new characters made the story all the more interesting. We finally get to see Kashou's parents and learn more about them and their motivations in relation to Kashou's choices. Given that the disapproval of his father's been a running back arc to the entire series, finally getting to see the reasons and effects of that was pleasing. The French characters, his mentor (whose name I keep forgetting, so just going to say 'mentor' to save hassle) and Fraise, also added a bit of colour. I admit Fraise might have been a little unnecessary at points, since her primary function seemed to be to highlight Kashou's kindness even in the past, which I think we've all got at this point in series, but she was entertaining anyway. His mentor was somewhat of a surprise, since I admit from the conversations with Maple in vol 3 I got the feeling his teacher was a guy, but she was certainly an important moving point in Kashou's arc. Plus, though not a 'new' character, seeing Milk's (however brief) return was a nice cameo, given her absence in vol 3.

All this being said though, there were a couple of things with the story that I think could have done with some tweaking. I'm avoiding spoilers, so don't want to say too much, but the 'twist' revealed at the end of chapter 5 was... well, the surprise was somewhat diluted by the fact that I'd already figured it out from the story told near end of chapter 4. I think a bit much might have been revealed before the 'big reveal', making that said big reveal a little flat. As Kashou himself later says, there were quite a few hints, and I'm not denying they were important to the story. But maybe they should have toned said hints down a bit so as not to ruin the reveal.

On a more minor note to the story, the scene where 4 of the girls help designing cakes was also a little odd. Given that it supposedly occurs in a single break-time, when there is no way in the world Kashou could have made that many cakes, especially given the last one's complexity, in so short a time. I know he's good, but that's a little beyond believable :)

And as a final negative note, the post-credits scene/chapter 6 worried me a bit, since, as I mentioned earlier, it suggests Shigure... going off the deep end a bit. If anyone's seen my reviews of earlier volumes, you'd know that I think Shigure's obsession was blown WAY over the top in vol 2 compared to how she was in vol 1, and that it went slightly more back to normal in vol 3. Vol 4 was actually really good with her depiction for most part, with her finally seeming more like her original version. But that one final scene blew it all up, and with what that means going forward to further versions... idk. It'd be a bit much.

Still, this was another outstanding piece in an already outstanding series, so 10/10 :) I really hope we get a vol 5 where we get to see some sort of resolution to the French characters' arcs. Granted I'm not sure how I feel about the possibility of Fraise ending up another catpanion, since just how many can one guy have before his body gives out? :D But I'd still love to see their characters developed further.

However, as much as i like this game and how hyped i was when i bought it, i felt like there are one particular thing from the story that can be improved, or i can say, missing thing..
We all know that Vol. 1 focused on Chocola-Vanila, vol. 2 was focused on Azuki-Coconut, and vol. 3 was focused on Maple-Cinnamon. But well, when i read that there will be a new catgirl in vol. 4, i expected that the story will be focused on that new character. But i guess my expectation was too high, and the story itself is focused on Kashou himself and his family (mom, dad, mentor). Fraise only got a few appearances throughout the game, lack of backstory for her, and yaa, just lack of Fraise content, which for me, is a disappointment.

Another thing is regarding the DLC (you know what i mean), i know that it's Valve who doesn't approve that DLC to be sold on Steam (and i know that other site such as Dlsite and Denpasoft are selling the DLC), But i don't understand why they doesn't approve the DLC but another adult games, which resemble real human, can be bought easily and are still available.

80435719.review:
OOOOOOOOOMMMMMMMMMMGGGGGGGGGGGG GIVE MEEE MOREEEEEEE AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Edit after playing the whole game, [u]spoiler free:[/u]

Nekopara volume 4 oh boy let me tell you this one has some spice in it and story to die for. When comparing to Volume 1 of the series this one might even beat it when judging how much new is introduced to the reader  and it makes you understand Nekopara universe better on a new level that no other volume has before.

A bit about the good stuff before I go, this might be a bit of a spoiler but more of a technical one rather than story and only is relevant to those who have the "patch" for this game. Feel free to skip this one if you feel like it.

[spoiler]So in this volume of nekopara there is an option to choose when "more wild" part is about to happen between "lewd option" and "more loving and no nudity having" scenes which in my personal experience is a huge upgrade and makes this game suitable for those too who are more into that sweet and romantic feeling.[/spoiler]

Overall I think Nekopara volume 4 is a great visual-novel. Not only it has one of the best stories to tell out of all Nekopara, it also has old good slice of life type of approach into small bakery's daily life and I'm already waiting to see what the sequel will bring to this exciting adventure which is spiced up with cute cat girls. 

Other ppl can think what they want to but I loved this one and I hope you give it a try too before judging it.

Overall rating by me: [b]85/100[/b] 
Mainly all the minus points due the art changes and story being kind of too predictable in certain parts.

Thank you for reading. Azuki is my favorite. Which one(s) is your favorite?

The story adds a few new characters including a new catgirl which at some point you will surely have relations with as you do with other peoples cats.

but heres the part of the review you actually care about

You can buy the 18+ patch on DLSITE for 50% off with a new account if you pay in yen.


edit: the jankiness in the animation seems to be caused partially by windowed mode, full screen mode works the same as windowed just move your mouse to the top.
a lot of other irregularities can be fixed by accessing the advanced settings, located in the help menu of all places.
